lessonActivities.title: SHALL ‚Äî Offers and Suggestions
lessonActivities.content:
'Shall' is commonly used with I and we to make polite offers or suggestions. It is more frequent in British English and formal contexts.

Examples:

  • Shall we go for a walk?
  • Shall I open the window?
examples: Shall we go for a walk?
Shall I help you with that?
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'shall' to offer or suggest, especially with 'I' and 'we'.

lessonActivities.title: WILL ‚Äî Future Actions, Promises & Predictions
lessonActivities.content:
'Will' expresses future actions, voluntary decisions, promises, and predictions. It's the common modal for future time in neutral English.

Examples:

  • I will call you tonight.
  • It will rain this afternoon.
lessonActivities.tips: Choose 'will' for straightforward future facts, promises, or voluntary actions.

lessonActivities.title: WOULD ‚Äî Conditionals, Past of 'Will', Habitual Past
lessonActivities.content:
'Would' is used in conditional sentences for hypothetical results, as the past form of 'will' in reported speech, and to describe repeated actions in the past.

Examples:

  • If I had time, I would travel more.
  • She said she would arrive by seven.
  • When we were kids, we would play outside every evening.
examples: If I had time, I would travel more.
She said she would arrive by seven.
When we were kids, we would play outside every evening.
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'would' for hypothetical situations, reported speech of 'will', and past habits.

lessonActivities.title: HAD BETTER ‚Äî Strong Advice and Warnings
lessonActivities.content:
'Had better' gives strong advice or warnings about likely negative outcomes. In speech it is often shortened to 'better'.

Examples:

  • You had better take your umbrella with you today.
  • That bus had better get here soon!
examples: You had better take your umbrella with you today.
That bus had better get here soon!
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'had better' to warn or strongly advise; in fast speech it's often 'better'.

quizActivities.question: Which modal completes this polite offer?
quizActivities.sentence: _____ we book a table for dinner?
quizActivities.explanation: 'Shall' makes a polite suggestion when used with 'we'.

quizActivities.question: Which modal expresses a promise?
quizActivities.sentence: I _____ finish the report by Monday.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Will' indicates a promise or voluntary future action.

quizActivities.question: Complete the conditional: 'If I were rich, I _____ travel the world.'
quizActivities.sentence: If I were rich, I _____ travel the world.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Would' is used for hypothetical outcomes in the conditional.

quizActivities.question: Which modal best fits this warning?
quizActivities.sentence: You _____ call the police if you see smoke.
quizActivities.hint: Use 'had better' to warn about possible danger.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Had better' warns of likely negative consequences if action is not taken.

quizActivities.question: Reported speech: 'He said he _____ come later.'
quizActivities.explanation: In reported speech the future 'will' is typically backshifted to 'would'.

quizActivities.question: Polite offer: '_____ I carry that for you?'
quizActivities.hint: 'Shall I...' is a polite way to offer help.
quizActivities.explanation: Use 'shall' for polite offers when the subject is 'I'.

quizActivities.question: Negative warning: 'You _____ not ignore that noise.'
quizActivities.hint: 'Had better not' expresses strong negative advice.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Had better not' warns against a dangerous or unwise action.

quizActivities.question: Past habit: 'Every summer we _____ visit the lake.'
quizActivities.sentence: Every summer we _____ visit the lake.
quizActivities.explanation: Use 'would' to describe habitual actions in the past.

quizActivities.question: Future prediction: 'I think she _____ accept the invitation.'
quizActivities.sentence: I think she _____ accept the invitation.

quizActivities.question: Formal usage: 'The committee _____ decide on the matter.'
quizActivities.sentence: The committee _____ decide on the matter.
quizActivities.hint: 'Shall' is used in formal or official contexts.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Shall' can indicate official decisions or obligations in formal language.
